articles.title: Japan Court Drops Key Legal Hurdle for Transgender People
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Participants at the Tokyo Trans March in Shibuya district of Tokyo, March 31, 2023. 
                    © 2023 Yuichi Yamazaki/AFP via Getty Images
          
    


  
A court in Japan has ruled that the legal requirement that transgender people alter the appearance of their genitals to change their legal gender is unconstitutional. The September 19 ruling of the Sapporo Family Court in Hokkaido prefecture adds to the nationwide momentum to respect trans people’s fundamental right to legal recognition.Since 2004, transgender people in Japan who wanted to legally change their gender needed to apply to a family court. Under the Gender Identity Disorder Special Cases Act, applicants must undergo a psychiatric evaluation, be surgically sterilized, and “have a physical form that is endowed with genitalia that closely resemble the physical form of an alternative gender.” They also must be single and without children who are younger than 18.In a 2023 case before the Supreme Court, a transgender woman argued that the sterilization requirement violated her rights to pursue happiness and to protection against discrimination. The 15 justices ruled unanimously that “being forced to undergo sterilization surgery ... constitutes a significant constraint on freedom from invasive procedures” in violation of Japan’s Constitution. It was only the twelfth time in modern Japanese history that the Supreme Court had found a law unconstitutional.When the Supreme Court ruled against the sterilization requirement, it also asked a lower court to review the requirement to have “genitalia that closely resemble the physical form of an alternative gender.” In 2024, the Hiroshima High Court ruled that mandating surgery for the appearance requirement in legal gender cases could be unconstitutional. The court held that hormone treatment could satisfy the requirement. Since then,courts have issued similar decisions, under which trans women must show penile atrophy and trans men clitoral enlargement, making the appearance requirement effectively a hormone requirement. However, therecent Sapporo ruling affirms that requiring trans people to use hormones to change the appearance of their genitals also violates constitutional protections.Japan’s national parliament, the Diet, has been debating for two years how to implement the Supreme Court’s ruling. The Sapporo decision makes it clear that a resolution is urgent, and that it should align with international human rights and global medical consensus: legal recognition of gender should be separate from gender-affirming medical processes and should be based on individual choice.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Participants at the Tokyo Trans March in Shibuya district of Tokyo, March 31, 2023. © 2023 Yuichi Yamazaki/AFP via Getty Images

A court in Japan has ruled that the legal requirement that transgender people alter the appearance of their genitals to change their legal gender is unconstitutional. The September 19 ruling of the Sapporo Family Court in Hokkaido prefecture adds to the nationwide momentum to respect trans people’s fundamental right to legal recognition.

Since 2004, transgender people in Japan who wanted to legally change their gender needed to apply to a family court. Under the Gender Identity Disorder Special Cases Act, applicants must undergo a psychiatric evaluation, be surgically sterilized, and “have a physical form that is endowed with genitalia that closely resemble the physical form of an alternative gender.” They also must be single and without children who are younger than 18.

In a 2023 case before the Supreme Court, a transgender woman argued that the sterilization requirement violated her rights to pursue happiness and to protection against discrimination. The 15 justices ruled unanimously that “being forced to undergo sterilization surgery ... constitutes a significant constraint on freedom from invasive procedures” in violation of Japan’s Constitution. It was only the twelfth time in modern Japanese history that the Supreme Court had found a law unconstitutional.

When the Supreme Court ruled against the sterilization requirement, it also asked a lower court to review the requirement to have “genitalia that closely resemble the physical form of an alternative gender.” In 2024, the Hiroshima High Court ruled that mandating surgery for the appearance requirement in legal gender cases could be unconstitutional. The court held that hormone treatment could satisfy the requirement. Since then,courts have issued similar decisions, under which trans women must show penile atrophy and trans men clitoral enlargement, making the appearance requirement effectively a hormone requirement. However, therecent Sapporo ruling affirms that requiring trans people to use hormones to change the appearance of their genitals also violates constitutional protections.

Japan’s national parliament, the Diet, has been debating for two years how to implement the Supreme Court’s ruling. The Sapporo decision makes it clear that a resolution is urgent, and that it should align with international human rights and global medical consensus: legal recognition of gender should be separate from gender-affirming medical processes and should be based on individual choice.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legal ruling in Japan that removes unconstitutional barriers for transgender people to change their legal gender without mandatory invasive surgeries or hormone treatments. This decision advances fundamental human rights and dignity for a marginalized group, has broad societal impact, and aligns with international human rights standards. The article provides detailed context on the legal background, court rulings, and ongoing legislative discussions, demonstrating substantial substance and significance.
articles.personality_title: Japan court removes surgery requirement for legal gender change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**  
Since 2004, transgender people in Japan who wanted to legally change their gender had to meet strict rules. These included being single, not having children under 18, undergoing psychiatric evaluation, surgical sterilization, and changing the appearance of their genitals to match the gender they identify with. These rules were part of a law called the Gender Identity Disorder Special Cases Act.

**What happened**  
On September 19, 2024, the Sapporo Family Court in Hokkaido ruled that the rule requiring transgender people to change the appearance of their genitals to legally change their gender is unconstitutional. This follows a 2023 Supreme Court decision that said forcing sterilization surgery on transgender people is against Japan’s Constitution. The Sapporo court also said that requiring hormone treatments to change genital appearance is unconstitutional.

**Impact**  
This ruling removes a major legal barrier for transgender people in Japan. It means they can seek legal recognition of their gender without having to undergo invasive surgeries or hormone treatments. This respects their personal choice and aligns Japan’s laws with international human rights standards. The decision is part of a growing movement in Japan to protect the rights and dignity of transgender people.

**What’s next step**  
Japan’s national parliament, called the Diet, has been discussing how to update the law for two years. The Sapporo court’s ruling adds pressure to create new rules that separate legal gender recognition from medical procedures. The goal is to allow people to change their legal gender based on their identity, without mandatory medical treatments.

**One-sentence takeaway**  
Japan’s courts are removing forced medical requirements for legal gender change, moving toward respecting transgender people’s rights and choices.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un tribunal japonais supprime l'exigence chirurgicale pour changer de genre légalement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**  
Depuis 2004, les personnes transgenres au Japon devaient respecter des règles strictes pour changer légalement de genre. Elles devaient être célibataires, ne pas avoir d'enfants de moins de 18 ans, passer une évaluation psychiatrique, subir une stérilisation chirurgicale et modifier l'apparence de leurs organes génitaux pour correspondre au genre choisi. Ces règles faisaient partie d'une loi appelée la Loi sur les cas spéciaux de trouble de l'identité de genre.

**Ce qui s’est passé**  
Le 19 septembre 2024, le tribunal de la famille de Sapporo à Hokkaido a jugé que l'exigence de modifier l'apparence des organes génitaux pour changer légalement de genre était inconstitutionnelle. Cela suit une décision de la Cour suprême en 2023 qui a déclaré que forcer la stérilisation est contraire à la Constitution japonaise. Le tribunal de Sapporo a aussi dit que l'obligation de suivre un traitement hormonal pour changer l'apparence des organes génitaux est inconstitutionnelle.

**Impact**  
Cette décision supprime un obstacle juridique important pour les personnes transgenres au Japon. Elles peuvent désormais demander la reconnaissance légale de leur genre sans subir d'opérations invasives ou de traitements hormonaux obligatoires. Cela respecte leur choix personnel et aligne les lois japonaises sur les normes internationales des droits humains. Cette décision fait partie d’un mouvement plus large pour protéger les droits des personnes transgenres.

**Prochaine étape**  
Le parlement japonais, appelé le Diet, débat depuis deux ans pour réviser la loi. La décision de Sapporo pousse à créer de nouvelles règles qui séparent la reconnaissance légale du genre des procédures médicales. L’objectif est de permettre aux personnes de changer légalement de genre selon leur identité, sans traitements médicaux obligatoires.

**Résumé en une phrase**  
Les tribunaux japonais suppriment les exigences médicales forcées pour changer de genre légalement, avançant vers le respect des droits et choix des personnes transgenres.
articles.personality_title_es: Tribunal japonés elimina requisito de cirugía para cambio legal de género
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**  
Desde 2004, las personas transgénero en Japón debían cumplir reglas estrictas para cambiar legalmente su género. Tenían que estar solteras, no tener hijos menores de 18 años, pasar una evaluación psiquiátrica, ser esterilizadas quirúrgicamente y cambiar la apariencia de sus genitales para coincidir con el género deseado. Estas reglas estaban en una ley llamada Ley de Casos Especiales de Trastorno de Identidad de Género.

**Qué pasó**  
El 19 de septiembre de 2024, el Tribunal de Familia de Sapporo en Hokkaido dictaminó que el requisito de cambiar la apariencia genital para el cambio legal de género es inconstitucional. Esto sigue a una decisión de la Corte Suprema en 2023 que dijo que forzar la esterilización viola la Constitución de Japón. El tribunal de Sapporo también dijo que exigir tratamientos hormonales para cambiar la apariencia genital es inconstitucional.

**Impacto**  
Esta decisión elimina una barrera legal importante para las personas transgénero en Japón. Ahora pueden obtener el reconocimiento legal de su género sin someterse a cirugías invasivas o tratamientos hormonales obligatorios. Esto respeta sus decisiones personales y alinea las leyes japonesas con los estándares internacionales de derechos humanos. La decisión es parte de un movimiento creciente para proteger los derechos de las personas trans.

**Próximo paso**  
El parlamento nacional de Japón, llamado Dieta, ha estado debatiendo durante dos años cómo actualizar la ley. La decisión de Sapporo presiona para crear nuevas reglas que separen el reconocimiento legal del género de los procedimientos médicos. El objetivo es que las personas puedan cambiar legalmente su género según su identidad, sin tratamientos médicos obligatorios.

**Resumen en una frase**  
Los tribunales japoneses eliminan los requisitos médicos forzados para el cambio legal de género, avanzando hacia el respeto de los derechos y decisiones de las personas transgénero.

articles.title: Moldova reaffirms its European direction in the parliamentary elections on Sunday
articles.summary: The electorate of the Republic of Moldova predominantly expresses its pro-European option in the parliamentary elections.
articles.content:
The electorate of the Republic of Moldova predominantly expresses its pro-European option in the parliamentary elections.

The electorate of the Republic of Moldova predominantly expresses its pro-European option in the parliamentary elections.

Chisinau/Bucharest – The Action and Solidarity Party (PAS, pro-European) from the Republic of Moldova comfortably won the parliamentary elections on Sunday and will have the majority in Parliament with 55 mandates, according to partial official results.

The new legislature in Chisinau will also include four other parties that have surpassed the thresholds set by law: the Patriotic Electoral Bloc (BEP), the “Alternative” Electoral Bloc (BEA), Our Party (PN), and the Democracy at Home Party (PPDA).

The President of Romania, Nicuşor Dan, congratulated the Moldovan citizens for their “firm” vote in favor of continuing the country’s European path and assured that Romania will continue to help Moldova in its European journey and will continue projects that bring prosperity and a better quality of life for its citizens.

The Romanian Prime Minister, Ilie Bolojan, sent a congratulatory message to the Moldovan voters for their mobilization in the parliamentary elections on Sunday and for voting in the European direction, reiterating that the place of the Republic of Moldova is “in the great European family.”

“Personally, but also on behalf of the Government of Romania, we will stand by the Republic of Moldova on this path,” assured the Prime Minister.

The Romanian MEP Victor Negrescu, Vice President of the European Parliament, commented that the victory of pro-European forces in the Republic of Moldova is a strong signal for accession to the European Union, and the Council must promptly approve the start of negotiations on chapters.

”Moldovan citizens have sent a clear message: they want a European future. The results show that, despite the challenges and manipulation campaigns aimed at destabilizing the electoral process, pro-European forces emerged victorious. This victory is one of values: democracy, rule of law, transparency, and European solidarity,” said Negrescu.

According to him, the Republic of Moldova and, in particular, President Maia Sandu have given a lesson in democracy and resilience to the Western world.

“As Vice President of the European Parliament responsible for relations with the Republic of Moldova, I assure you of the full support of the European legislature. Europe and Romania win, and the Republic of Moldova is heading towards a common future with the European Union. By the end of 2028, the accession negotiations with the European Union can be finalized,” Negrescu conveyed.

The Republic of Moldova has candidate country status for accession to the European Union.

According to the latest official data, over 850,000 of the 2.4 million inhabitants of the Republic of Moldova have acquired Romanian citizenship between 1991 and 2024. (29.9.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant democratic event where Moldova's electorate decisively chose a pro-European parliamentary majority, signaling a strong commitment to democracy, rule of law, and European integration. This political development has broad societal implications for Moldova's future and regional stability, supported by international actors, and represents a meaningful step toward improved governance and quality of life for Moldovan citizens.

**Impact** – This election result shows that most Moldovan voters want their country to become part of Europe. articles.title: Why I want Nike, Adidas and Puma to sell single shoes
articles.summary: Former Para-athletic world champion Stef Reid says footwear companies are failing amputees.
articles.content:
Why I want Nike, Adidas and Puma to sell single shoes

2 hours ago Share Save Alex Taylor BBC News reporter Share Save

BBC Morning Live Former Para-athletic world champion Stef Reid wants sport footwear companies to match their inclusive marketing with genuine action

Stef Reid grew up as a sports-obsessed child, dreaming of playing rugby internationally. But on the eve of her 16th birthday, her life changed forever. Severe propeller lacerations from a horrific boat accident left doctors with no choice but to amputate her right foot. Initially she continued to pursue rugby, but her agility and speed weren't the same and she grew tired of comparing her performance to when she had both feet. "I didn't want to give up on my goal just because I was an amputee, but life is constantly changing and we have to update our goals instead of forcing them to work in a reality that no longer exists," she says. So she moved on from rugby and took up athletics. Using a light, springy carbon-fibre blade on her right leg, she eventually became a world champion Paralympic long jumper and sprinter for both Canada and Great Britain - winning medals, breaking records and receiving an MBE. She's now retired from professional sport, but has shown a similar adaptability and resilience in her new career which includes acting, modelling and broadcasting including competing in Dancing on Ice. Now she's campaigning for big brands such as Nike, Adidas and Puma to sell single shoes rather than pairs. In part it's about cost - high-end running shoes cost around £200, and when she was competing she only needed one but had to buy two, meaning she wasted hundreds of pounds on shoes she never wore.

But her biggest motivation - is the principle. Many of the big brands proudly display models with blades in their shop windows, but don't sell shoes individually for athletes like Stef. "I loved the bladed mannequins, and I wish 15-year-old Stef had seen those. "But now I want retailers to match their inclusive imagery with the actual buying experience". Stef isn't alone. While she wears two shoes with her day-to-day prosthetic, many other amputees don't. And beyond disability, thousands of people whose feet are different sizes are also affected by having to buy two shoes of the same size rather than two singles.

Stef Reid Stef says global sports brands are yet to match their inclusive marketing with useful action for amputees needing single shoes

Nike launched a single shoe programme last year, letting customers buy one shoe at half price at select stores. However this is not clearly advertised, requires the customer to contact the care support team and is not available online. When Stef raised the issue, she was not pointed to the scheme but instead offered a one-time 15% discount. "That's not much use in the long term, as I'm always going to have one foot".

BBC Morning Live In recent years, shops have incorporated disability into their marketing, prominently featuring mannequins wearing running blades

Adidas, which equip the British Paralympic team, also do not sell single shoes online. However they say it is possible to buy a single shoe in some stores, depending on stock. The company added it is in the "advanced stages" of finalising a comprehensive policy. Puma meanwhile, does not sell any single shoes in store or online and, like Decathlon, did not respond to a request for comment. While Nike and Adidas have made positive steps towards addressing the issue, Stef thinks sports brands should sell single shoes at all their shops and online as standard practice.

Small steps

Some smaller businesses and grassroots organisations are already proving it is possible.

High street footwear company Schuh sells single shoes for half the price of a pair, while shoe chain Office also allows you to buy odd sized pairs of shoes through their outlet site. And then there's small scale solutions such as Jo's Odd Shoes, founded by Jo O'Callaghan who lost her right leg to complex regional pain syndrome. The condition makes it too painful to wear a prosthetic limb, leaving her, like many amputees, only needing one of a pair of shoes. She set up a Facebook Group where members could swap or donate spare shoes. Many retailers also donate shoes to the scheme. The items are free for members, aside from a small fee for postage and packaging.

BBC Morning Live Jo, seen dealing with online orders, says her initiative offers her peace of mind in knowing that shoes will not go to waste

It's a service that air sport athlete Jack Pimblett has benefited from. Born with talipes, or club foot, which stunted the growth of his right foot and leg, he struggled to find two shoes which fitted well when he was younger. He often had to put cotton wool in his shoes to fill the extra space. As an adult, he manages by buying a combinsation of junior and adult shoe sizes - buying a right shoe in size 5 and a left shoe in size 7. But this imposes a significant financial strain, with Jack typically spending around £150 for two pairs of shoes. "It would be nice to be able to buy shoes that fit… [without] paying twice," he says. Stef acknowledges the change she's calling for takes time and money, but urges firms to push forward. "All it takes is that first step forward in the right direction," she says.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an important accessibility and inclusivity issue affecting amputees and people with different sized feet, advocating for sports brands to sell single shoes. This change would have a meaningful, broad impact on many people, addressing a real-world problem of waste, cost, and inclusion. The story focuses on a clear, single topic with detailed context and examples, including efforts by smaller businesses and grassroots initiatives, making it an inspiring call for systemic change in retail practices.
articles.personality_title: Former Paralympic champion urges sports brands to sell single shoes for amputees
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Stef Reid, a former Paralympic world champion who lost her right foot in a boat accident before turning 16, has experienced firsthand the challenges of buying shoes as an amputee. Although major sports brands like Nike, Adidas, and Puma promote inclusivity in their advertising, they do not widely offer single shoes for people who only need one.

**What happened** – Stef Reid is campaigning for sports companies to sell single shoes instead of pairs. When competing, she used a special carbon-fiber blade on one leg and only needed one running shoe, but had to buy two, wasting money on a shoe she never wore. She found that Nike offers a limited single shoe option but with unclear availability, while Adidas and Puma have few or no options. Smaller companies and community groups have started providing single shoes or shoe swaps to help.

**Impact** – This issue affects many people beyond amputees, including those with feet of different sizes. Buying two matching shoes forces them to spend extra money and creates waste. Stef’s campaign shines a light on the gap between brands’ marketing and the real needs of customers. It also encourages more inclusive shopping experiences that better reflect the diversity of people’s feet.

**What's next step** – Stef hopes that big brands will make single shoes a standard option both in stores and online. Adidas says it is working on a policy, while others have yet to respond fully. Meanwhile, grassroots efforts like Jo’s Odd Shoes provide free shoes to amputees through donations and swaps, showing practical ways to support this need.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Stef Reid’s call for sports brands to sell single shoes highlights a simple but important change that can save money, reduce waste, and make shopping more inclusive for amputees and many others.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une ancienne championne paralympique demande aux marques de sport de vendre des chaussures à l’unité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Stef Reid, ancienne championne du monde paralympique qui a perdu son pied droit dans un accident de bateau avant ses 16 ans, connaît bien les difficultés d’acheter des chaussures en étant amputée. Bien que des grandes marques comme Nike, Adidas et Puma affichent l’inclusion dans leur publicité, elles ne proposent pas largement la vente de chaussures à l’unité pour ceux qui n’en ont besoin que d’une.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Stef Reid milite pour que les marques de sport vendent des chaussures à l’unité plutôt qu’en paire. Lorsqu’elle concourait, elle utilisait une lame en fibre de carbone sur une jambe et n’avait besoin que d’une chaussure de course, mais devait en acheter deux, gaspillant ainsi de l’argent pour une chaussure non portée. Nike propose une option limitée, peu claire et difficile à trouver, tandis qu’Adidas et Puma offrent peu ou pas de solutions. Des petites entreprises et associations communautaires commencent à proposer des chaussures à l’unité ou des échanges.

**Impact** – Ce problème touche aussi bien les amputés que les personnes ayant des pieds de tailles différentes. Acheter deux chaussures identiques leur coûte plus cher et crée du gaspillage. La campagne de Stef met en lumière le décalage entre la publicité des marques et les besoins réels des clients. Elle encourage une expérience d’achat plus inclusive, adaptée à la diversité des pieds.

**Prochaine étape** – Stef espère que les grandes marques proposeront la vente de chaussures à l’unité comme option standard en magasin et en ligne. Adidas travaille sur une politique, mais d’autres n’ont pas encore répondu pleinement. Pendant ce temps, des initiatives comme Jo’s Odd Shoes offrent gratuitement des chaussures aux amputés grâce à des dons et des échanges, montrant des solutions concrètes.

**Une phrase clé** – L’appel de Stef Reid à vendre des chaussures à l’unité montre un changement simple mais important pour économiser de l’argent, réduire le gaspillage et rendre le shopping plus inclusif pour les amputés et bien d’autres.
articles.personality_title_es: Ex campeona paralímpica pide a marcas deportivas vender zapatos individuales para amputados
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Stef Reid, ex campeona mundial paralímpica que perdió su pie derecho en un accidente de barco antes de cumplir 16 años, conoce bien las dificultades de comprar zapatos siendo amputada. Aunque marcas grandes como Nike, Adidas y Puma muestran inclusión en su publicidad, no ofrecen ampliamente la venta de zapatos individuales para quienes solo necesitan uno.

**Qué pasó** – Stef Reid está haciendo campaña para que las marcas deportivas vendan zapatos individuales en lugar de pares. Al competir, usaba una cuchilla de fibra de carbono en una pierna y solo necesitaba un zapato de correr, pero tenía que comprar dos, desperdiciando dinero en un zapato que nunca usaba. Nike tiene una opción limitada y poco clara, mientras Adidas y Puma ofrecen pocas o ninguna solución. Pequeñas empresas y grupos comunitarios ya ofrecen zapatos individuales o intercambios.

**Impacto** – Este problema afecta a muchas personas más allá de los amputados, incluyendo quienes tienen pies de diferentes tamaños. Comprar dos zapatos iguales les obliga a gastar más y genera desperdicio. La campaña de Stef destaca la diferencia entre la publicidad de las marcas y las necesidades reales de los clientes. También impulsa experiencias de compra más inclusivas que reflejen la diversidad de los pies.

**Próximo paso** – Stef espera que las grandes marcas hagan de la venta de zapatos individuales una opción estándar en tiendas y en línea. Adidas dice que está trabajando en una política, mientras otros aún no responden completamente. Mientras tanto, iniciativas como Jo’s Odd Shoes ofrecen zapatos gratis a amputados mediante donaciones e intercambios, mostrando soluciones prácticas.

**Una frase clave** – La petición de Stef Reid para vender zapatos individuales señala un cambio sencillo pero importante que puede ahorrar dinero, reducir desperdicios y hacer las compras más inclusivas para amputados y muchos más.

articles.title: Nepal highlights youth-driven change, and calls for global action
articles.summary: Nepal’s UN Ambassador Lok Bahadur Thapa delivered a comprehensive address to the General Assembly’s high-level debate on Monday, emphasising both domestic reforms and the urgent need for international solidarity to tackle global crises.
articles.content:
He framed Nepal’s recent challenges and achievements as part of a broader call for strengthened multilateral action.

Mr. Thapa opened by noting the youth-led political movement earlier this month – the “Gen-Z protests” – which demanded transparent governance, equal opportunities across Nepalese society and an end to corruption.

“Their aspirations are for nothing less than a fair, just and prosperous Nepal,” he said, while also lamenting the violence that claimed lives and damaged public infrastructure during the demonstrations.

He highlighted the subsequent political milestones following the transformational protests, including the appointment of the country’s first female Prime Minister and the upcoming general elections in March 2026.

Mr. Thapa described these developments as steps toward consolidating democracy, rebuilding institutions and restoring public trust.

World at a crossroads

Turning to global concerns, Ambassador Thapa warned of rising military expenditures, unmet commitments to sustainable development and the worsening climate crisis.

He said they were a reminder that multilateral institutions, including the UN, must be revitalised to respond effectively.

He also addressed ongoing crises worldwide, including the war in Ukraine and conflicts in Sudan and the Sahel. He highlighted the “heavy toll” borne by civilians in Gaza, while calling for the immediate release of all hostages, including a Nepalese student taken by Hamas during the October 7 attacks in Israel.

Call for global solidarity

Mr. Thapa called for accelerated progress toward the 2030 Agenda and ambitious climate action, emphasising emissions reduction and scaling up renewable energy.

He also highlighted the need for fairer global representation in international financial institutions and the Security Council – calling for them to become more inclusive, transparent and accountable.

Recalling that the UN has served for 80 years as a beacon of peace, justice, human rights, and development, Ambassador Thapa concluded with a plea for collective responsibility:

“When the United Nations succeeds, humanity as a whole succeeds. When it falters, it is the innocent and the vulnerable who bear the heaviest cost. Let us stand together, united and determined, to ensure enduring peace and prosperity in the world.”
